Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.633 - Western Amazon Floodplain Forest NT'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.633 - Western Amazon Floodplain Forest NT'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.El.633 - Western Amazon Floodplain Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.El Amazonian Swamp & Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Los bsq de igapó se encuentran sobre llanuras aluviales planas a ligeramente deprimidas, con suelos arenosos principalmente blancos, con altas concentraciones de sustancias tánicas y acidos húmicos debido a la descomposición de la materia organica

Biotic-processes.Summary: Los bsq de varzea estan sujetos a las fluctuaciones del nivel del rio, pueden estar inundados de 3 a 5 meses o permanentementeLos bosques de igapó son de menor estatura, menos densos y menos ricos que los bosques de varzea

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq de varzea estacional, 2. Bsq de Igapó (aguas negras, blancas y claras) Se encuentran en la Amazonia occidental de Colombia, Ecuador, Perú y Brasil, en este último hacia el oeste del rio Jaruá
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.4.El.633 - Western Amazon Floodplain Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: None of the evaluated indicators reached the thresholds for Vulnerable for any criteria, but it almost reached the threshold for criterion and could become Vulnerable soon. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Bolivia
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.4.El.633 - Western Amazon Floodplain Forest' macrogroup in Bolivia.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for CO was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for CR for subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.634 - Western Amazon Swamp Forest VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.634 - Western Amazon Swamp Forest VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.El.634 - Western Amazon Swamp Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.El Amazonian Swamp & Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: alta precipitación Los suelos presentan un aporte continuo de aguas de escorrentia, con drenaje lento, generalmente se encuentra rodeada de cuerpos de agua estacionales o permanentes

Biotic-processes.Summary: Es comun la formacion de turba

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq amazonico inundado (permanentemente) Se distribuye en la cuenca occidental del Amazonas, al noreste de Perú, Colombia, Ecuador y Brasil, hacia el oeste del rio Jaruá
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Eastern Cordillera real montane forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.635 - Southwestern Amazon Floodplain Forest VU (NT -- VU)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.635 - Southwestern Amazon Floodplain Forest VU (NT -- VU)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.El.635 - Southwestern Amazon Floodplain Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.El Amazonian Swamp & Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Characteristic-biota.Taxon: Manilkara bidentata ssp. surinamensis (= Manilkara surinamensis)

Biotic-processes.Summary: Los bsq de varzea varian en funcion de la ubicacion y el nivel de inundación, con periodos de 3-4 meses. Bosques altos (25-30 m), tienen un dosel irregular y varios estratos. Los bsq de igapó de aguas negras representa un complejo tipos de bosques incluyendo los de la ribera, depresiones y lagunas circundantes.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. varzea inundables, 2. Bsq. de igapó (aguas blancas, negras y claras) Se encuentran al suroeste de la Amazonia de Bolivia, Perú y en Brasil en las cuencas altas y medias del rio Purus y Madeira
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.4.El.635 - Southwestern Amazon Floodplain Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criterion. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os NT -- VU.

Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for CR was reached for criteria.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of recent change in woodland cover reached the threshold for CR for subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was evaluated, but the uncertainty in the estimates of predicted future changes in tree cover was too high to reliable assign a category.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.636 - Southern Amazon Swamp Forest VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.636 - Southern Amazon Swamp Forest VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.El.636 - Southern Amazon Swamp Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.El Amazonian Swamp & Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Biogeographic-region: Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.4.El.636 - Southern Amazon Swamp Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Assessment-unit.name: Bolivia

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Bolivia
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.4.El.636 - Southern Amazon Swamp Forest' macrogroup in Bolivia.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of NT -- LC.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Subcriterion.name: A3

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.637 - Northern Amazon Floodplain Forest NT (NT -- VU)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.637 - Northern Amazon Floodplain Forest NT (NT -- VU)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.El.637 - Northern Amazon Floodplain Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.El Amazonian Swamp & Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: . Los bsq inundables se presentan en depresiones o terrazas bajas con suelos hidromorficos y acidos

Biotic-processes.Summary: Los bsq inundables de aguas blancas y claras presentan bosques altos con multiples capas

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq inundable (Aguas blancas), 2. Bsq de pantano Se distribuye en Colombia en la cuenca inferior del rio Caqueta y en las sub-cuencas del rio Apaporis, y en la subcuenca del rio Japurá en Brasil
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Guianan piedmont and lowland moist forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.4.El.637 - Northern Amazon Floodplain Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: None of the evaluated indicators reached the thresholds for Vulnerable for any criteria, but it almost reached the threshold for criterion and could become Vulnerable soon. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os NT -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.638 - Central Amazon Floodplain Forest VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.638 - Central Amazon Floodplain Forest VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.El.638 - Central Amazon Floodplain Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.El Amazonian Swamp & Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Los bsq de varzea se estiende a lo largo de los rios mientras la topografia sea plana, estan en llanuras de inundacion de aguas blancas, las zonas mas bajas presentan periodos de inundacion de 7 meses a 1 año

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq varzea estacionales, 2. Bsq de igapó (aguas blancas, negras y claras) Se encuentran en la cuenca baja y media de la amazonia de Brasil.
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Guianan piedmont and lowland moist forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.4.El.638 - Central Amazon Floodplain Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.639 - South-Central Amazon Floodplain Forest VU (NT -- VU)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.639 - South-Central Amazon Floodplain Forest VU (NT -- VU)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.El.639 - South-Central Amazon Floodplain Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.El Amazonian Swamp & Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq varzea estacionales, 2. Bsq de igapó (aguas blancas, negras y claras) Se distribuye en Bolivia al sur de la cuenca amazonica y en Brasil en las llanuras de inundacion de los rios Madeira y Tapajoz
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.4.El.639 - South-Central Amazon Floodplain Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criterion. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os NT -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: None of the evaluated indicators reached the thresholds for Vulnerable for any criteria, but it almost reached the threshold for criterion and could become Vulnerable soon. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.640 - Amazon Delta Swamp Forest VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.4.El.640 - Amazon Delta Swamp Forest VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.4.El.640 - Amazon Delta Swamp Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.4.El Amazonian Swamp & Flooded Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: En las islas los suelos son arcillosos con material transportado del rio.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Las palmeras son el elemento forestal mas visible. Los bosques mas al exterior presentan un regimen de inundación por mareas y presentan comunidades de pantano. Mas hacia el interior en tierra firme crecen de 2-3 m se parecen mas a los bsq de varzea y se inundan con menos frecuencia.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠For the tropical and temperate flooded and swamp forest formations, permanent and temporal water bodies form a relevant element of the ecosystem and interact with characteristic biota (e.g. species tolerant to flooding and high ground water levels) and important processes (e.g. nutrient cycling, vegetation growth; Keddy et al. 2009)⁠. We considered flood regime and surface water as an important component of these forest macrogroups.

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq de pantano del Amazonas, 2. Estuarios del amazonas Se encuentran en la cuenca baja del Amazonas y en las islas, como la isla de Marajo.
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: Global 200 ecoregion 'Amazon River and Flooded Forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.
